children.subject: Yeah lol, could be much worse
Thank you! That's a very fair and balanced policy imo.
That's right. You can choose what appears on your university transcript, but your choice won't affect whether you can declare the CS major.
So basically the grade in 61A, 61B and 70 will be computed for declaration purposes either way, but will not be included in GPA calculation if we choose to take them as PNP.
An NP would be substituted for the letter grade you would have earned (D+, D, D-, or F) and included in your GPA along with the grade you receive upon retaking the course.

I'm curious about the policy regarding getting a NP this time. Is it the same as Spring where the NP will be substituted and not considered in declaring major. Or will both the NP and retake grades be considered this time?
<md>seems that everything else is as usual, if you got GRD: A- (EPN: P) this sem and A+ next sem your gpa for that course is 3.85</md>
Oh, so the average of the two will be taken?
If you take a declaration course multiple times, all grades will be included in your GPA calculation.
Are you allowed to retake courses for which you received a grade of C or higher? For example, a student receives a B in cs61a this semester, then an A- next semester.
Nope, at a campus level that's not allowed

Will we be able to take one of the three prerequisite classes for P/NP this semester, ask for our letter grade, and then retake it next semester and use the grade from next semester for deceleration calculation? 

It wasn't specified here, so I'm assuming we can not do so. I was just wondering if this is the same type of rule as Spring 2020.
I took a gap semester, so I'm not really up to date on this. Do you mind explaining how those classes had reduced workload?
DeNero states above these classes have had course content reduced due to online learning difficulties and the pandemic.
So they had reduced content, but that doesn't really affect the difficulty of projects/tests, right?
I'm just assuming that the scope of content covered will be reduced

@Calc, yep I believe so. For 61a, they did make some lectures optional and reduce the homework/project load (sadly, it's only ~8 ECs, not 10 anymore :( ).

There also is a new thing like reverse ED and a new way of taking the exam, but you can abuse code.cs61a.org and unlimited cheatsheet... So it's kind of balance out I guess
Thank you to both of you!

> Do you mind explaining how those classes had reduced workload? Sure, I took 61a this summer and I can confirm from the summer coursework, this semester's 61A definitely has a lower scope (I'm sad at that since macros, TCO, variadics, as well as the full ants and scheme project, were my favorite parts of the course but I am also grateful that Prof DeNero is understanding to students in this semester and is making sure that what he does deliver is the same quality as regular semesters while lowering project workloads to help students in this pandemic). I'm also taking 61B and have noticed a large amount of the class (everything in pink here: http://fa20.datastructur.es/ is out of scope as well which have been covered in past exams for both Prof Hug and Hilfinger in the past — though recent Hilfinger finals are hard to find). There have also been ~15 slip days you can use which has been really helpful and imo was a really smart move. and 70 hasnt really been affected as much in terms of content from what ive seen but note 18 applications is optional and there was some shuffling around in the order variance was taught wrt lecture but I don't think any of the total amnt of actual content covered changed (some semesters don't cover graph theory, markov chains, or computability at all) but there have been various accommodations such as a multitude of vitamin and homework drops (i think 3 or 4 of each) and the piazza support from 70 instructors for homework threads has been great (whenever there are typos or ambiguities in homework questions they clear it up there and usually reduce the weightage of that question or make it optional — they made a good portion of this week's homework optional since it wasnt covered in lecture as much as they wanted it to be). They have also made certain vitamins questions graded on effort-based completion and take out questions if they feel it is too hard. All 3 declaration classes definitely have reduced workloads and this post (about L&S PNP) existing are evidence that the university cares about its CS students which is great to see!
<md>3 hw drops in cs70, not 4. </md>
<md>and the default is 2</md>
Considering remote learning will continue for Spring 2021, can students taking CS 61a/b and 70 next semester expect the same reduced course content in these courses as Fall 2020?

Are you L&S? If so, it should be fine.

If you are COE you should definitely wait for a policy to be announced since none has been so far (not safe to pnp as of rn)
So as of now, is it safe to P/NP my classes (CS 70 & EECS 16A)? Or should I wait a little longer for more updates?

I think "any other P or NP grades in Fall 2020 or Spring 2021 relevant to declaration" refers to courses other than 61a/b/70. Most students won't need anything other than those three. But in cases like transfer students who completed a partial equivalent to 61b, they can take 47b instead of 61b to count towards their declaration GPA.
The response above is correct — for 61b, you don't need a grade memo.

“For any other P or NP grades in Fall 2020 or Spring 2021 relevant to declaration (in most cases, there are none), students must provide a grade memo from their instructor indicating what their letter grade would have been, and this letter grade will be used in place of the P.” 

If I decide to PNP 61b, should I also my instructor to provide a grade memo? I am confused by what does for any other P or NP grades mean.
Yes. We would use grade memos for the Fall 2020 and Spring 2021 grades. You have the option to exclude your CS61A Spring 2020 grade, if that helps your GPA for the major.
Ok, thanks so much!

Say we took 61a as PNP last semester (Spring 2020) because we had that option. If we take 61b as PNP this semester (Fall 2020) and CS 70 as PNP next semester (Spring 2021) because we have those options, would we be allowed to do that? Will the CS department still consider only the grades we would have received instead of the P or NP during the declaration process?
Yes, it's OK to PNP CS47B and it will have the same weight (1 unit). You would need to request a grade memo from the faculty in this case since it's not CS61AB or 70.
Thanks!
Are we allowed to P/NP CS 47B? Also, would CS 47B still have the same weight (1 unit) in the GPA for declaring?
16b isn't one of the three courses that is used in declaration, so I'm pretty sure it doesn't make a difference.
The only way your 16b grade would be included is if you were enrolled in CS 70 in Spring 2020.
If we took 16b pnp in spring 2020, can we request that its grade get counted in for declaration?
Yep, assuming you're L&S CS and not CoE EECS
We're also allowed to take CS61C and EECS16B as PNP for Spring 2021 right? Since they're considered major requirements, but their grades aren't considered for the GPA calculation?
You can take any CS or EECS classes as PNP for spring 2021 even if they are major declaration requirements afaik as long as you are L&S, though I could be mistaken
are we still allowed to take the major requirements like Math 1B, EECS16A as P/NP for this year?
Yes, you can take 70 P/NP, but the letter grade you would have gotten will be used to determine your declaration eligibility, so make sure to do your best in the course even if you're enrolled P/NP.
Thank you for the clarification!

Hello, 

if a student declares a CS major in L&S with only one course, in my case it is CS 70, and 61a and 61b were taken in a city college, and they are transferable, is it still valid to take CS70 for P/NP ?

My understanding is that the calculated grade would be used for declaring the major, but it would have no effect on GPA?

Thank you!

Please see Carol's response to your email sent to cs-advising. This will not affect your ability to graduate with CS.

Next time, please email us OR post us here so we're not duplicating work. Thanks!
I declared as a cs major in letter and science college. I took ee16a as a pass degree, and I am taking ee16b right now. I want to change ee16b to p/np. Will it affect me get a cs degree?
You will need to check with UPE.

They will not count, UPE simply receives a list of the highest GPAs from the department and having PNP grades count would require us to differentiate which were PNP’d because of the pandemic and which were normal PNP courses — UPE just gets a list of the top third highest overall GPAs, not top 3rd declaration GPAs
Would these grades used for declaration be used in the calculation of GPA for eligibility to UPE? Or will they not count the grades received in the classes we decide to PNP?
<md>61A, 61B, and 70 letter grades will be shared with the department. No action is required by students to make these grades visible to the declaration committee.</md>
Thank you very much!

those of us that are taking the class as P/NP and are trying to declare L&S CS, are our letter grades already shared with the EECS department or do we have to manually request for them?

Given those of us that chose P/NP this semester for CS declaration classes (CS61A/B and 70), are our letter grades already shared with the committee approving our major or should we request the letter from our professors and report them to CS declaration committee? By CS declaration committee, I mean the people who review and make decisions on our CS major declaration application.
You can either leave it as not available or if you know your grade, enter the grade. We will verify the grade with the faculty.
On our major application, do we report our equivalent grade if we took a course PNP, or as “not yet available”? I do not see a P option

It's typical for it to take 3+ weeks after the application deadline for everyone to be declared. We process all the apps and declare everyone at once. We have over 400 apps this time and will need to wait to receive the grades from the faculty, so end of January is probable.
Should we expect to receive our CS declaration email this week?
We sent out the notifications yesterday (or the day before?).
When should we expect to hear from the major application decisions?

Don't want to blame anyone, but I just feel sad. I found myself getting pushed back by 50 ppl on the waitlist of 184 because they think I'm "not" a cs major. I really hope the declaration process can go a lot faster.

history.content:
This academic year has been particularly difficult for many students. To accommodate the challenges associated with remote learning and the pandemic, Fall 2020 offerings of CS 61A, CS 61B, and CS 70 are reducing the set of topics covered on assignments and exams relative to an on-campus semester. However, grades in these courses will be considered for declaration.

Policy:

Electing P/NP grading for CS 61A, CS 61B, or CS 70 in Fall 2020 and Spring 2021 will neither help nor hinder a student's application to declare the L&S Computer Science major. In particular, for students taking CS 61A, CS 61B, and/or CS 70 in Fall 2020 and Spring 2021:

1) Letter grades will be computed for all students, regardless of the grading option they elect (letter grade or P/NP). These letter grades will be shared with students and the EECS department.

2) For L&S CS major admission purposes, only the letter grades computed in this way will be used to determine the declaration GPA. When a student applies to declare the L&S CS major, the EECS department will substitute all P and NP grades on their transcript from Fall 2020 and Spring 2021 with the corresponding letter grade they would have received.

For example, if a student transcript shows CS 61A (B+ grade), CS 61B (A- grade), CS 70 (P grade), and the letter grade they would have received in CS 70 had they elected letter grading is a C+, this student’s major declaration GPA is a 3.1. The 3.1 does not meet the 3.30 GPA requirement.

3) For any other P or NP grades in Fall 2020 or Spring 2021 relevant to declaration (in most cases, there are none), students must provide a grade memo from their instructor indicating what their letter grade would have been, and this letter grade will be used in place of the P.

Notes:

Prior to this policy, a P grade was treated as a C- for L&S CS major declaration purposes.

Students denied during the declaration process may appeal, as always. Contact cs-advising@cs.berkeley.edu for more info.

The Spring 2020 policy regarding P/NP grades applies only to courses taken in Spring 2020.

This policy does not affect College of Engineering students.

Links:

Computer Science Major Declaration Policies:
https://eecs.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate/cs-ba

Spring 2020 policy regarding P/NP grades:
https://piazza.com/class/hyq0br1u3kx7dg?cid=11615

College of L&S P/NP Policy for Fall 2020 and Spring 2021:
https://lsadvising.berkeley.edu/fall-2020-and-spring-2021-policy-modifications-and-faq
history.subject: Fa20 and Sp21 L&S CS Declaration Policy
